index.p1: I build moving images that are sharp and emotive. My eye is shaped as much by cinema as by design schools: Villeneuve's precise composition, Burton's playful madness, Nolan's epic scale, and Tarantino's razor-edged rhythm.
index.p2: For me, motion design is about rhythm: shaping beats so the audience knows exactly what to feel and when. Every project starts with the same question: what should the audience feel—and what's the most direct way to show it?

about.lead: Motion Designer & Title Designer. I design sequences that are clear and emotive for film, series, games, and brands.

background.title: Parcours
background.bio1: At ESDAC I built strong foundations in Graphic Design, focusing on color and observational drawing, thanks to inspiring teachers who shaped the way I still see and build images today. During my apprenticeship at France Sport, I learned to adapt quickly to a professional environment, proving reliable and effective in a fast-moving team.
background.bio2: At ArtFx I sharpened my eye across photography, sculpture, painting, drawing, and film/VFX. Working on many group projects taught me to keep workflows clean, readable, and handoff-ready.
background.bio3: At Objectif3D I developed my 3D skills and studied semiology, learning how images, symbols, and composition guide meaning.
background.bio4: I also studied computer science for two years, which gave me a strong sense of logic and discipline in structuring projects.
background.bio5: Finally, at MJM I brought all of this together in Motion Design — applying everything I had learned — and graduated with honors.

whatido.title: What I do
whatido.item1: Title design & animated typography (main titles, interstitials, on-air graphics)
whatido.item2: 3D-driven spots and graphic sequences (from styleframes to animatics to final renders)
whatido.item3: Hybrid workflows (Cinema 4D/Redshift ↔ After Effects) with clean, disciplined comps
whatido.item4: Editorial clarity: shaping beats so the audience always knows what to feel and when

how.title: How I work
how.step1: Question the brief → <span class='italic'>what should the audience feel?
how.step2: Prove it fast → styleframes and timing tests, no mystery reels.
how.step3: Design for constraints → GPU/RAM, deadlines, local vs. farm render.
how.step4: Name and structure everything → tidy files, handoff-ready projects.
how.step5: Keep it non-destructive → layers, precomps, nodes: always editable, because change will come.

tools.title: Tools
tools.text: Cinema 4D + Redshift, After Effects, Photoshop, Illustrator, X-Particles when needed. Git-based versioning for assets, and a bias toward automation over manual tweaking.

influence.title: Influences
influence.p1: Cinema is my biggest teacher. Denis Villeneuve inspires me for his rhythm, storytelling, and composition. Dune: Part Two was such a reference for me that I even made a project around it during my studies — its sense of scale and control of pacing are masterful. Blade Runner 2049 speaks to my love of cyberpunk, with immaculate visuals and a story that flows like music. Villeneuve is a genius of cinematography — every film he releases seems to claim the Oscar for it.
influence.p2: Tim Burton shaped my taste for playful madness. Beetlejuice (both 1 and 2) with its delirious mix of animatronics and stop motion, and Alice in Wonderland with its sheer fun, show his joy of creation. Yet he can also break your heart, as with Edward Scissorhands. He is a master of both humor and storytelling.
influence.p3: Christopher Nolan is my reference for epic tension. Dunkirk is my favorite: the sound design and relentless pacing make you feel trapped inside the atrocity of war. With The Dark Knight, he mixes suspense, tension, and even humor at the highest level — the Joker remains unforgettable.
influence.p4: Quentin Tarantino is the undisputed master of absurd carnage. Pulp Fiction, Kill Bill, Inglourious Basterds, Once Upon a Time in Hollywood — each shows his talent for rhythm, dialogue, and violence turned into spectacle.
influence.p5: Video games taught me just as much. Cyberpunk 2077 for its storytelling and rhythm, Journey for its visual composition and purity, and Gris for its color, rhythm, immersion, and delicate storytelling. Both Cyberpunk 2077 and Gris even made me cry — proof that when rhythm, image, and narrative align perfectly, motion can reach straight into emotion.
influence.p6: Music is my metronome: from orchestral weight to electronic textures, it dictates the cuts and crescendos in my work.

working.title: Working with me
working.text: Those who worked with me — teachers, mentors, and companies — have praised my adaptability, professionalism, and motivation. My approach is collaborative and clear: pointing out weaknesses is just a step toward making the work stronger.
working.text2: I'm also open to any suggestion that can improve the project, whatever its source. Freelance and remote-friendly, in English or French. Open to international clients and co-direction with studios.
